content: The United States has had persistent trade deficits since 1978, with significant deficits with countries like China, the European Union, Japan, and Mexico. Despite having open borders, the US faces trade barriers with its partners. Establishment of the Emergency Trade Deficit Commission with 11 members appointed by the President, Senate leaders, and committee members to represent various interests. The Emergency Trade Deficit Commission consists of 11 members appointed by the President, Senate leaders, and committee members to represent various interests. Members are appointed based on qualifications and restrictions, ensuring a diverse representation. The Emergency Trade Deficit Commission appoints members with expertise in economics, trade, manufacturing, labor, environment, or business, who are not US officers or employees. Efforts are made to ensure diverse perspectives and fresh insights on addressing trade imbalances. The Emergency Trade Deficit Commission appoints members with expertise in economics, trade, manufacturing, labor, environment, or business, who are not US officers or employees. Members are appointed within 60 days of the Act's enactment for the life of the Commission. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission holds its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed, with meetings called by the Chairperson. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for decision-making, and each member is entitled to one vote. The Emergency Trade Deficit Commission appoints members with expertise in various fields. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for decision-making, with each member entitled to one vote. SEC. 3. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is tasked with examining the causes of the US trade deficit, including macroeconomic factors like currency practices and foreign government purchases of US assets. They are also required to assess the impact of tariff and nontariff barriers on trade deficits with specific countries. The Commission is required to assess the impact of trade deficits with specific countries, including the effects of tariff and nontariff barriers, investment requirements, technology transfer, labor standards, environmental protection, and enforcement of environmental laws. The Commission is mandated to evaluate the impact of trade deficits with specific countries, considering tariff barriers, investment requirements, technology transfer, labor standards, and environmental protection. Additionally, it must analyze the effects of free trade agreements, investment flows in and out of the United States, outbound investment impact on the trade deficit, and the relocation of production facilities overseas on the trade deficit. The Commission will review major domestic plant closures to determine production relocation offshore, assess the impact of foreign direct investment and bilateral investment treaties on the trade deficit, analyze the role of energy imports, and evaluate how foreign policy influences economic and trade policies. The Commission will analyze the consequences of the United States trade deficit, including its impact on the domestic economy, manufacturing capacity, job quality, wages, and environmental standards. It will also assess how trade deficits affect defense production, innovation capabilities, and economic growth. Recommendations will focus on strategies to improve trade balances with countries having significant deficits and identify trade policy tools. The United States aims to address trade deficits through various policy tools, enhance competitiveness of manufacturers globally, improve coordination among federal agencies, and enhance trade data collection and reporting. The Commission is required to submit a report containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations to the President and relevant committees within 16 months of the Act's enactment. Members can also include additional views in the report. The Commission is granted powers outlined in Section 5. The Commission, as outlined in Section 5, has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and use postal services. Additionally, Section 6 addresses personnel matters of the Commission. The Commission members are compensated based on their status as government employees or not, with travel expenses covered. The Chairperson can appoint an executive director and staff without following civil service laws. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and staff without following civil service laws. The compensation for the executive director and personnel is determined by the Chairperson, with limitations on pay rates. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. Temporary and intermittent services can be procured as needed. The Chairperson of the Commission can procure temporary and intermittent services under specific regulations without interrupting civil service status or privilege. SEC. 7. Authorization of $2,000,000 for the Commission. GAO to audit financial records after Commission termination. SEC. 8. Commission terminates 30 days after report submission. SEC. 9. Moratorium on free trade agreements until Commission report delivered.
